lines.content: This document records my use of AI tools during the development of this project.
AI was used primarily as a **language refinement and review tool** to adjust the personality and phrasing of Neko‚Äôs chat messages after updating the project theme.
- Improve consistency of tone across commands.
- Rewrite error messages to be playful but still clear and professional.
- Maintain concise and readable user-facing output.
- Review validation logic for potential missed edge cases.
- Generating alternative phrasings for user-facing messages.
- Ensuring consistent personality across `todo`, `deadline`, `event`, `snooze`, and error responses.
- Identifying a missing edge case in `parseEvent()` (empty date after `/from` or `/to`).
- Suggesting clearer and more user-friendly error wording.
No parsing logic, control flow, or algorithmic implementation was generated by AI.
All validation conditions, command dispatch logic, and structural design were manually implemented.
- Helped quickly generate multiple tone variations.
- Improved consistency of personality across commands.
- Helped surface a subtle validation blind spot.
- Reduced time spent manually rewriting repetitive message blocks.
- Some AI suggestions were overly dramatic or emoji-heavy and needed simplification.
- Validation logic still required manual reasoning and verification.
- Edge-case coverage required careful manual inspection.
- Final phrasing was manually refined to maintain clarity and professionalism.
Core implementation and validation logic remained manually designed and tested.
AI was used as a **support tool for phrasing and review**, not as a code generator.
It accelerated stylistic refinement and helped identify minor validation gaps.
Final responsibility for correctness, robustness, and compliance with coding standards remained manual.
AI was used to draft the initial structure and wording of this `AI.md` file.
- Ensure clarity and professionalism in documentation.
- Structure the reflection in a concise and readable format.
- Phrase the usage log objectively and accurately.
- Avoid under-reporting or over-reporting AI involvement.
- Organizing sections (Purpose, What Worked, Reflection, etc.).
All decisions regarding what to include, what to omit, and how to accurately represent AI involvement were made manually.
This increment is intentionally self-referential: AI was used to document the use of AI.
However, AI served only as a drafting and formatting assistant.
The content reflects my actual usage and decisions.
Estimated time saved: **10‚Äì15 minutes** in structuring and polishing documentation.
This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Neko.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Neko.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

Neko is your little digital companion that keeps track of your tasks so nothing slips through your paws. Simple, fast, and always reliable.
Adds a todo task without any date.
Adds a new todo task to the list.
Hehe~ I've added this for you:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list, nya.
Adds a task with a deadline.
Adds a deadline task with the specified due date.
Hehe~ I've added this for you:
Now you have 2 tasks in the list, nya.
## Adding an event : `event DESCRIPTION /from YYYY-MM-DD /to YYYY-MM-DD`
Adds a task that occurs over a time period.

Now you have 3 tasks in the list, nya.
Shows all tasks in the list with their index numbers.

Marks the specified task as completed.
Good job! I marked this as done, nya~

Hmm~ not done yet? I unmarked it for you.
Deletes the specified task from the list.
Roger nya! I have deleted this task:
Now you have 2 tasks in the list.
Finds tasks containing the specified keyword.
Displays all tasks whose descriptions contain the keyword.
I found them nya! Here are the matching tasks in your list.
## Snoozing a deadline or event: `snooze INDEX DAYS`
Postpones a deadline or event task by a number of days.
Updates the deadline of task 2 by 3 days.
Nya! I have snoozed this task:
Aww‚Ä¶ leaving already? I‚Äôll be here when you‚Äôre back, nya~
